text: okay the next talk is going to be by bradley alicia and colleagues purposefully non-standard cybernetics an alternative to purpose-driven control this is going to be a one-hour pre-recorded talk so thank you enjoy
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Hello, my name is Dr. Bradley Elisaia, and on behalf of Jesse Parent, Morgan Huff, and Amanda Nelson, we're from the Orthogonal Research and Education Laboratory and the Cybernetics Interest Group, and I'm going to talk to you today about purposefully non-standard cybernetics, an alternative to purpose-driven control.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we start with a question.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: What is the definition of behavior?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This has varied throughout history.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: According to the behaviorists, behavior was identified as a reflex elicited by stimulus associations, the consequence of reinforcement, and the current motivational state.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If we go forward to the cognitivists, which is more or less the modern view, they would say that behavior is a set of internal mental states that are responsible for observable behaviors.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: with goal-directed end states.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Now, it's of note that both behaviorist and cognitivist views involve feedback.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This leads to learning, a notion of what constitutes a state, and predictive capacity.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we start with this paper, Rosenbluth et al.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: in 1943, Behavior, Purpose, and Teleology, published in the Philosophy of Science, and it's a formative paper in the field of cybernetics.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So in that paper they have this typology of behavioral classifications.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we're going to return to this typology throughout the talk and we're going to think about how we can reorganize this typology.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But it basically defines behavior as a set of nested things.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The red text, non-classes, or they're basically all other things other than the black thing that we'll be talking about at each rung of this typology.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So behavior is active.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's purposeful.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It involves feedback, which implies some sort of teleology.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: or end goal.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's also predictive, which involves extrapolation and involves an order of prediction.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So you might have first order, second order, or third order prediction.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So to understand what teleology is and where it comes from, we start at the Middle Ages where teleology was the end state or the end goal of some behavioral process.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It was thought of as divine causation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We then move forward to teleology as natural causation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Then it branches off into two directions, and the first was the vitalism of Bergson
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and evolution by natural selection, made famous by Darwin.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Leading from Darwin's work, we had Ernst Marr, who talked about teleonomy, which is purpose versus history, and we'll talk a little bit about that later in the talk.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Kind of discontinuous to this are two different streams.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the first at the top is where behavior is viewed as habit.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That's by William James and Thorndike.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That leads us to the molecular antiteleology of Francis Crick.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And feedback is complexity, which is summarized by control theory and dynamical systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: At the bottom is our target paper that we just talked about.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: These are the views of Rosenbluth and Weiner, and this is feedback relative to a goal.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This led us to cognitive science and reinforcement learning, or at least the modern versions of this, where people talk about goal-directed behavior, and variations on that in molecular biology, such as molecular vitalism,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and the TAME and UAL methodologies of Levin, Jablanka, and Ginsburg.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we'll talk about a couple of papers here and frame some of this in context.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So if we think about behavior, it's essentially a form of functionalism.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In the first paper here, Roddy and Germain, they argue that functionalism is a pre-scientific
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So they actually argue that the whole idea of functionalism is something that comes from this era of divine causality.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Biology is not designed, so why should we expect a function?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this is something that, of course, maybe is assumed about function, that it comes from some sort of design or comes from some sort of divine intervention.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: On the other hand, teleonomic systems are defined by spatial and temporal information and constant iterations over states.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we do have these teleonomic systems, but include modern components.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Only select behaviors can be defined as selection of a goal or derived from signals from the goal.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So that means that we can't necessarily paint behavior with a broad brush of teleology.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Only some behaviors may be teleological and others may be not.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Not all behaviors, and this includes biological and machine behaviors, are goal-selecting.

text: And while goal-directed behaviors seem to be purposeful, and it may be true that some of these behaviors that are known as goal-directed are purposeful, are there developmental and evolutionary antecedents?

text: And the answer may be no.

text: So Rosenbluth et al.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: defined behavior as any change in an agent with respect to its surroundings.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is much broader than the neuroscience psychological definition, and it's a contrast between all behaviors and a subset of purposeful behaviors.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So if a behavior is put under some sort of selection, or if a behavior is selection of something in the environment, this might lead us to a subset of voluntary behaviors, which then some of those may be purposeful.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so purposeful behaviors is actually a subset of all behaviors.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: To demonstrate this, we see that clocks, both mechanical and biological, are not purposeful, because there is no final aspirational state.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Mechanical clocks can keep time, and you can set an alarm on them, but that alarm is imposed by the outside, and it's not a property of that behavior in and of itself.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Furthermore, a biological clock runs via physiological processes like a circadian rhythm,

text: So it's some sort of signal from a goal that's specific to that behavior and purposes progress to that goal.
